Car Payment Formula

Your monthly car payment is calculated using:

M = P × (r × (1 + r)^n) / ((1 + r)^n - 1)

Where: P = Loan amount, r = Monthly interest rate, n = Number of payments

This formula accounts for the principal and interest portions of your payment.

Frequently Asked Questions

How much should I put down on a car?

A down payment of 20% is recommended to avoid negative equity, but many loans allow as little as 0-10%. A larger down payment reduces your loan amount, monthly payments, and total interest paid.

What's a good interest rate for a car loan?

Good rates vary by credit score: excellent credit (720+) can get 3-5%, good credit (680-719) gets 5-8%, and fair credit (620-679) gets 8-15%. Shop around for the best rates from multiple lenders.

How long should my car loan term be?

Shorter terms (36-48 months) mean higher payments but less total interest. Longer terms (60-84 months) mean lower payments but more total interest. Consider your budget and financial goals.

Should I finance through the dealer or my bank?

Compare rates from both sources. Dealers may offer incentives but could have higher rates. Your bank or credit union might offer better terms. Get pre-approved to negotiate from a position of strength.

What's included in my monthly car payment?

Your payment typically includes principal and interest. It may also include sales tax, registration fees, and other charges depending on your state and how you structure the loan.

Car Buying Tips

  • Get pre-approved for financing before visiting dealerships
  • Check your credit score and improve it if necessary
  • Shop around for the best interest rates from multiple lenders
  • Consider the total cost of ownership, not just the monthly payment
  • Factor in insurance, maintenance, and fuel costs
  • Don't forget about trade-in value if applicable
  • Read all loan terms and conditions carefully
  • Consider a larger down payment to reduce monthly payments
